En cambio, un matrimonio es un contrato público entre dos personas, reconocido por la sociedad y por la ley, que confiere derechos y obligaciones específicas a ambas partes. En este sentido, el matrimonio representa un nivel más alto de compromiso y responsabilidad mutua. Además, el hecho de que se haya prometido pero no se haya casado aún deja abierta la posibilidad de que estos planes se alteren, se reorganicen o se cancelen antes de que se realice el matrimonio. Esto puede deberse a diversos factores, como cambios personales, circunstancias económicas, problemas familiares o incluso decisiones individuales. Por lo tanto, aunque la promesa de casarse puede ser muy significativa para los involucrados, no tiene la misma legalidad o consecuencias establecidas que un matrimonio formal.

He felt that the moment had come for making his adieux to Sibyl Vane. There was something tragic in the air. He wondered how soon he would hear of her death. It seemed to him that he had loved her profoundly. All his sensations seemed to be wrapped in a mist. He felt a vague dissatisfaction with life, like a man who has smoked too much opium, and wants fresh excitement. He thought of the picture that Basil had painted of her, and decided that the artist had been the father of a new school of beauty. Certainly, Sibyl Vane was beautiful; but beauty in women is a passing flower. He had seen the like before. The sudden flushing of the cheeks, the bright, pleading eyes, the curling lips, were the same old, weary romance that had been played so often in the world. It was an age-old story. He grew weary of it, as one grows weary of a theme that one has often heard performed. There was nothing new in the boy's passion. It was the same old tragic love story as ever, with a slight variation of detail. He remembered the description that Oscar Wilde had once written of the passion that had stirred another artist. The lad was fine-looking and fascinating. But it was all the tyranny of the flesh, he thought, and the idle dreams of youth. He wondered how soon the lad would be back among his books and his paints, working hard to pay for the folly that had made him throw away a fortune. The pity of it! He felt a pang of chivalrous sorrow. Yet he was not sorry for the boy's mistake. He felt rather glad that he had been able to love so much. It was a proof of his capacity for passion. Passion was the finest thing in the world. It made everything else seem trivial. He remembered the charming boyish figure of Dorian Gray, with his waving hair, his fine, golden beard, and his passionate eyes that seemed to seek something on one's soul. He missed him already. The friendship between them would be a loss to both. And yet, what could he do? Sibyl Vane was ruined. It was a hideous, terrible thing. He felt sorry for her, and pitied the mother and the father. He wished he could help them. But he could not. And now the picture had to be hidden away, and the friendship had to be sacrificed. It was all too dreadful. As the house became still, Lord Henry Wotton lit a cigarette, and sighed. The joy had passed out of his life. He felt that he would never again know what it was to be young.

The evidence of his senses told him that the picture was unchanged. It was his own soul that had altered. Remorse, like a sharp-toothed beast, had gnawed at him till he was but a mere shadow of his former self. He could not help looking on evil as the one reality. Good, in his eyes, seemed to be but a spectral theory, a cipher to be solved, or a phantom to be chased across the pinpricked darkness. The beauty that had once seemed to him to be a reality, to which all else was subordinate, appeared to him now as mere appearance, and not the true essence of life. He grew cynical about art, and his love for it left him. He would have destroyed the picture, but dared not. It had become his confessor, and he knew that if he attempted to mar its beauty, he would be laying bare his own soul. He felt that the eyes of the portrait had grown cunning. They seemed to mock his attempts to hide from himself. He began to wonder whether it would not be better for him to leave London, to hide himself in some remote place, where he would be unknown, and where the secret of his life would be safe. The thought of a new life, of a life freed from the horrible fascination of that unchanging face, was pleasing to him. Yet he hesitated. The picture had become his confidant, and he was afraid to trust himself alone with his thoughts. Besides, he had a curious craving to see the picture again, to confirm for himself that it had not altered. The mere act of looking at it fascinated him. He would sit for hours gazing at it, wondering what would happen if he could throw a jar of acid over it, or tear it into shreds. He felt that the picture had become his curse, his embodiment of sin, and yet he hesitated to destroy it.
